coredata.dc:title: A star polymer POSS-PMMA based gel electrolyte with balanced electrochemical and mechanical properties for lithium metal battery

Luo, Cong
Niu, Yanhua
Li, Guangxian
coredata.dc:description: Gel polymer electrolyte (GPE) is one of the promising candidates to overcome the defects of liquid and solid electrolyte for lithium metal batteries (LMBs). The obstacle for the practical application of GPEs lies in achieving a balance between ion transport, mechanical properties and interface stability. In this work, a star shaped polymer matrix polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane-polymethyl methacrylate (POSS-PMMA) is successfully synthesized with POSS as the core via atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) method. 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazole bis(trifluoromethanesulfon)imide ([EMIM][TFSI]) and bistrifluoromethanesulfonimide lithium salt (LiTFSI) are blended with the matrix to increase ionic conductivity. Attributed to the star structure and the lithium ion migration channel provided by POSS, the synthesized GPE possesses excellent balanced mechanical and electrochemical properties. To further stabilize the Li/GPE interface, a polymer and plastic crystalline electrolyte (PPCE) is coated as interface modification layer on both sides of GPE. Benefitting from the design, the synthesized GPE reaches a highly stable Li striping/plating cycling for 1000 h at 0.1 mA cm−2 with ionic conductivity of 3.5 × 10−4 S cm−1, Li+ transference number of 0.35, and electrochemical stability window of 4.9 V. Furthermore, the Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||LiFePO4 (LFP) full cell shows a high capacity retention of 99.5 % after 100 cycles at 0.2 C under room temperature (RT), and the high voltage Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||LiNi1-x-yMnxCoyO2 (NCM811) cell shows a high capacity retention of 88.3 % after 50 cycles at 0.1 C under RT. This work opens up a new frontier to stabilize the Li/GPE interface and enables safe operation of room temperature lithium metal batteries.

Star polymer
Gel polymer electrolyte

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Schematic illustration of (a) synthesis of POSS-PMMA and (b) fabrication process of POSS-PMMA GPE and POSS-PMMA-PPCE GPE.

(a) FTIR spectra and (b) 1H NMR spectra of POSS, PMMA and POSS-PMMA with different arm lengths. (c) The GPC results of POSS-PMMA. (d) DSC curves of POSS-PMMA with different arm lengths. (e) Rheology master curves of POSS-PMMA with different arm lengths at a reference temperature of 150 °C.

(a) The ionic conductivity σ of POSS-PMMA based GPE with different arm lengths at room temperature. (b) Arrhenius plots of ionic conductivity of PMMA/POSS-PMMA based GPE. (c) Electrochemical window of POSS-PMMA based GPE. (d) Current-time curve obtained from chronoamperometry at a DC polarization. (e) The stress-strain curves of PMMA/POSS-PMMA based gel electrolyte. (f) The TGA curves of PMMA/POSS-PMMA based GPE. (g) Transport model of Li+ in PMMA/PMMA-POSS based GPE.

(a) XRD patterns of PPCE, SN, PEO, and LiTFSI. (b) The EIS spectra of Li symmetrical cells of POSS-PMMA-PPCE/POSS-PMMA based GPE. (c) Galvanostatic cycling curves of Li||Li symmetric cells with POSS-PMMA-PPCE/POSS-PMMA/PMMA based GPE at 0.1 mA cm−2 and RT. (d) Galvanostatic cycling curves for Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||Li cells at 0.2 mA cm−2 and RT. (e) SEM images of the surfaces of the Li anode of the Li||Li symmetric cells with the PMMA, POSS-PMMA and POSS-PMMA-PPCE based GPE after 50 cycles at 0.1 mA cm−2.

XPS of the Li metal surfaces after cycling with different GPEs after 50 h at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 and RT. The high-resolution (a) C 1s, (b) F 1s, (c) N 1s and (d) Si 2p. Schematic illustration of the electrochemical behavior of lithium metal anode with (e) POSS-PMMA-PPCE based GPE and (f) PMMA based GPE.

(a) Rate capability of Li||POSS-PMMA||LFP and Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||LFP cell. (b) Charge/discharge curves of Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||LFP cell at different rates. (c) Long cycle performance of Li||PMMA||LFP, Li||POSS-PMMA||LFP and Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||LFP at 0.2 C and RT. (d) Rate capability of Li||POSS-PMMA||NCM811and Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||NCM811 cell. (e) Charge/discharge curves of Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||NCM811 cell in the first turn at each rate. (f) Long cycle performance of Li||PMMA||NCM811, Li||POSS-PMMA||NCM811 and Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||NCM811 at 0.1 C and RT.

head.ce:title: A star polymer POSS-PMMA based gel electrolyte with balanced electrochemical and mechanical properties for lithium metal battery

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Gel polymer electrolyte (GPE) is one of the promising candidates to overcome the defects of liquid and solid electrolyte for lithium metal batteries (LMBs). The obstacle for the practical application of GPEs lies in achieving a balance between ion transport, mechanical properties and interface stability. In this work, a star shaped polymer matrix polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane-polymethyl methacrylate (POSS-PMMA) is successfully synthesized with POSS as the core via atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) method. 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazole bis(trifluoromethanesulfon)imide ([EMIM][TFSI]) and bistrifluoromethanesulfonimide lithium salt (LiTFSI) are blended with the matrix to increase ionic conductivity. Attributed to the star structure and the lithium ion migration channel provided by POSS, the synthesized GPE possesses excellent balanced mechanical and electrochemical properties. To further stabilize the Li/GPE interface, a polymer and plastic crystalline electrolyte (PPCE) is coated as interface modification layer on both sides of GPE. Benefitting from the design, the synthesized GPE reaches a highly stable Li striping/plating cycling for 1000 h at 0.1 mA cm−2 with ionic conductivity of 3.5 × 10−4 S cm−1, Li+ transference number of 0.35, and electrochemical stability window of 4.9 V. Furthermore, the Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||LiFePO4 (LFP) full cell shows a high capacity retention of 99.5 % after 100 cycles at 0.2 C under room temperature (RT), and the high voltage Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||LiNi1-x-yMnxCoyO2 (NCM811) cell shows a high capacity retention of 88.3 % after 50 cycles at 0.1 C under RT. This work opens up a new frontier to stabilize the Li/GPE interface and enables safe operation of room temperature lithium metal batteries.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: No data was used for the research described in the article.

ce:section.ce:para: Over the last two decades, lithium ion batteries (LIBs) are widely used in portable electronic products, electric vehicles and other high-tech fields around the world. But due to the theoretical energy density limit of LIB approaches, it is fail to meet the needs of the next generation batteries [1,2]. To solve this and other increasingly severity problems such as flammability and explosive, a large amount of research on lithium metal batteries (LMBs) emerge [3–6]. However, a series of severe problems of LMBs including Li anode pulverization and interface deterioration are still hinder its further practical application. In view of the above problems that cause the battery failure, the structural design of electrolyte is considered to be extremely significant [7–10]. Recently, quasi-solid-state lithium metal batteries (QSSLMBs) were proposed as one of the most competitive LMB systems due to its safety and high-energy-density using GPEs as electrolyte [11,12].

GPE is a promising electrolyte with a three-dimensional network structure with self-supporting properties and high mechanical strength, which combines the characteristics of liquid electrolyte (LE) and all solid polymer electrolyte (ASPE) [13,14]. To a certain extent, GPEs retain the advantages of the mechanical properties and safety properties, while the introduction of liquid plasticizers could further promote the dissolution of lithium salts and the migration of lithium ions, so that GPEs has higher ionic conductivity and better Li/GPE interface [15,16]. In general, GPEs are composed of polymer based material frame, lithium salt and liquid plasticizer [17], among which the polymer matrix commonly includes polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA), polyethylene oxide (PEO), polyacrylonitrile (PAN), poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropylene) (PVDF-HFP) [18–23].

Due to the low cost, simple synthesis and especially high liquid electrolyte uptake, PMMA becomes one of the most popular polymer matrix of GPE, but the poor film formability and weak mechanical properties of PMMA based GPEs limit their applications [24,25]. The introduction of nanoparticles such as SiO2, vinyl trismethoxy silane (VTMS) and polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS) is an effective method to improve the performance of PMMA based GPEs [26–28]. But the aggregation of nanoparticles also brings deterioration of conductivity and mechanical properties to some extent. Due to the relative low surface energy, channels for the migration of lithium provided by the three-dimensional nano-structure, and richness of reactive group on the surface such as vinyl groups and halogen atoms, POSS has been attracted much attention in recent years [29,30]. Either by blending or free radical copolymerization, the POSS has been introduced to PMMA based GPEs and improved mechanical and electrochemical properties have been obtained [30,31]. However, the current studies almost neglected the cycling performance and the mechanism of ion transport is not clear. For star shaped polymer, POSS as a crosslinking point could enhance the connection of PMMA chain at a lower content, thereby improving its mechanical properties, but the Li+ conduction is also trapped by chain entanglement [32]. Therefore, the appropriate molecular weight of each branch is the key to obtain GPE with good balanced mechanical and electrochemical performance. On the other hand, bad cycling performance caused by interface failure is also a serious obstacle preventing PMMA based GPEs from being used in batteries. Due to the super-activity of lithium metal, the easily formed fragile solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) can be punctured by lithium dendrites, significantly increasing internal cell impedance and ion transport barrier, ultimately leading to battery failure [33,34]. Coating an interface layer on the surface of polymer matrix is another strategy to further improve the long-cycle stability of GPEs [12,35]. Therefore, the design not only on the structure of molecular level but also on the interface level is of great significance to the LMBs with balanced mechanical and electrochemical properties.

Herein, a star shaped polymer POSS-PMMA with different arm lengths is first synthesized by ATRP method, based on which the ionic liquid [EMIM][TFSI] and LiTFSI are blended to form GPEs. To balance the mechanical and electrochemical properties, a POSS-PMMA sample with a fixed arm length (4 entanglement points) is employed to assemble LMB. Meanwhile, a multilayer structure with a special PPCE layer is constructed for a better interface stability. Attributed to the arm entanglement, a network structure could form with POSS as crosslinking points, which affords excellent mechanical properties of the GPE. In addition, the channels for the migration of lithium provided by POSS results in good electrochemical properties. Therefore, the prepared POSS-PMMA-PPCE with the arm length of 200 exhibits a higher ionic conductivity of 3.5 × 10−4 S cm−1, a wider electrochemical stability window of 4.9 V, and a Li+ transference number (tLi+) of 0.35. The PPCE coated on the electrolyte surface can not only significantly enhance the affinity with the anode but also participate in the formation of more stable SEI. These factors allow highly stable cycling for 1000 h at 0.1 mA cm−2. Besides, the Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||LiFePO4 cells (loading = 1.1 mg cm−2) exhibit a steady cycle performance with a capacity of 114.3 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.2C and room temperature (RT). The Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||NCM811 (loading = 1.0 mg cm−2) high voltage cells maintain a discharge capacity of 93.6 mAh g−1 after cycles at 0.1C and RT. This study provides the inspiration to achieve a balance between mechanical and electrochemical properties and long-term cycling of PMMA based GPEs.

Methyl methacrylate (MMA), Octachloropropyl silsesquioxane (POSS–Cl8), Cuprous chloride (CuCl), PMMA (M w = 120000 g/mol), Pentamethyldiethylenetriamine (PMDETA) and bistrifluoromethanesulfonimide lithium salt (LiTFSI) were purchased from Aldrich. 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazole bis(trifluoromethanesulfon)imide ([EMIM][TFSI]) was purchased from Shanghai Chengjie Chemical Co., Ltd, PEO, (M w = 200,000 g/mol), fluoroethylene carbonate, Dimethylformamide (DMF), tetrahydrofuran (THF), N-Methylpyrrolidone (NMP), anhydrous methanol and succinonitrile (SN) were obtained from Aladdin. LiFePO4 (LFP), LiNi1-x-yMnxCoyO2 (NCM811), PVDF and Super-P were purchased from Guangdong Canrd New Energy Technology Co., Ltd.

MMA, toluene, CuCl need further purification before use, and POSS-Cl8 and CuCl were dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C. The POSS-Cl8 as initiator, MMA as monomer (the molar ratio of POSS:PMMA is 1:600/800/1600/4000/4800, depending on the aiming arm length), and CuCl, PMDETA as catalytic system, whose molar ratio with POSS-Cl8 is fixed as CuCl:PMDETA:POSS-Cl8 = 8:24:1.The toluene with volume equal to MMA is as the solvent. The polymerization reaction was conducted at 110 °C for 24 h with continuous stirring in a special reaction flask. Before reaction, three rounds of liquid nitrogen freezing, vacuuming and thawing were conducted to grantee the anhydrous oxygen atmosphere. The flask with polymerized product was quenched to 0 °C to end the reaction, after that the product was dissolved in a large amount of tetrahydrofuran. Then, the dissolved polymer solution was passed through a neutral alumina column to purify POSS-PMMA. Finally, the purified solution was pulled into a large amount of anhydrous methanol and then the POSS-PMMA precipitation was obtained by filtering. The obtained POSS-PMMA was dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C before use.

POSS-PMMA (35 wt%) with different arm lengths, [EMIM][TFSI] (52 wt%), and LiTFSI (13 wt%) were dissolved in tetrahydrofuran (THF) and homogenously mixed in an argon-filled glove box (H2O＜0.1 ppm,O2＜0.1 ppm). The uniformly mixed solution was casted to a tetrafluoroethylene disc to volatilize the THF. Then, the prepared electrolyte membranes were dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C until a constant weight to obtained GPEs.

LiTFSI, PEO and fluoroethylene carbonate were dissolved in molten SN and stirred for 4 h at 60 °C (the mass ratio of LiTFSI: PEO: fluoroethylene carbonate: SN is 10: 3: 3: 60). The mixture was cooled down to RT to obtain solid-state PPCE. The prepared PPCE layer was uniformly coated on the surface of POSS-PMMA based GPE by immersion method at 60 °C.

The LFP/NCM811, PVDF and Super-P were dissolved in NMP at a mass ratio of 8:1:1 and stirred for 24 h to obtain electrode paste. The slurry is evenly coated on the aluminum foil and dried at 60 °C for 24 h to form a lithium metal cathode. The coin battery is assembled by sandwiching a 200 μm thick GPE between the prepared cathode and Li metal anode. All procedures were conducted in an argon-filled glove box (H2O＜0.1 ppm,O2＜0.1 ppm).

For clarifying the chemical structure of POSS-PMMA, gel permeation chromatograms (GPC), fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) characterizations were performed. The relative molecular weights of POSS-PMMA with different arm lengths were determined by the GPC of Waters 1515 with chromatographically pure tetrahydrofuran as elution solvent. FTIR spectra were collected on a Thermofisher Nicolet 6700 spectrometer equipped with a DTGS detector after 32 sweeps, with the resolution of 4 cm−1. The proton (1H) spectra were measured on a Bruker ADVANCE III HD NMR spectrometer operating at 400 MHz and using CDCl3 as solvents.

The rheological measurements were conducted on a stress-controlled rheometer TA DHR-3 using parallel-plate fixtures (with 25 mm diameter). The steady shear was performed from 0.01 to 100 s−1. The surface morphologies of the samples were observed by FE-SEM, Apreo S HiVac scanning electron microscope. The energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mappings of all samples were collected on the EDAX Genesis system. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) experiments were conducted on a TA Q20. All the samples were first heated to 160 °C and isothermal for 5 min to eliminate thermal history, then quenched to −80 °C and isothermal for 3 min and finally heated to 160 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The sample weigh is about 5∼10 mg, and all the experiments were conducted under the purge of nitrogen atmosphere. All tensile tests were conducted on a universal tensile testing machine XLD-1000E. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on TGA 550, TA Instrument, Inc, and the samples were heated to 700 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) spectra were measured on a powder diffractometer (Rigaku D/Max-3c X-ray diffractometer) with Cu Kα (λ = 0.154 nm) operating at 40 kV and 30 mA. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha+) was used to investigate the compositions of the SEI.

The ionic conductivity was measured with the symmetric stainless steel (SS)/GPE/SS cell by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) test on an electrochemical working station (INTERFACE 1010, GAMRY). The frequency range was 1.0 Hz–1.0 MHz and the temperature covered from 30 to 80 °C. The ionic conductivity was calculated by Eq. (1):

Where L and S are the thickness and area of the GPEs membrane, the bulk resistance R b was measured by AC impedance.

The Lithium transference number (t Li+) for POSS-PMMA was measured in a lithium-lithium symmetrical cell by chronoamperometry and AC impedance at RT. Initial current I 0 and steady-state values Is were obtained from the DC polarization measurement. The value of t Li+ was calculated by Eq. (2):

Δ V
, 100 mV), respectively.

The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was tested with the lithium sheet (Li)/GPE/SS cell (stainless steel as working electrode and lithium metal as reference and counter electrodes.). The voltage scanning rate was 5.0 mV s−1, and the potential range was 0∼7.0 V. The lithium striping/plating experiments were carried out in a Neware (CT-3008W) battery test system at RT.

Fig. 1 is a schematic illustration of synthesis of POSS-PMMA matrix, the fabrication of POSS-PMMA based GPE, and construction of POSS-PMMA-PPCE based GPEs. As shown in Fig. 1a, the crosslinked POSS-PMMA is successfully synthesized via ATRP. The arm length is tuned by the ratio of MMA and POSS. As illustrated in Fig. 1b, POSS-PMMA based GPEs are fabricated by co-solvent volatilization. To stabilize the Li/GPE interface, PPCE solution is coated on the surface of POSS-PMMA based GPEs at 60 °C. The layered POSS-PMMA-PPCE based GPEs are obtained by cooling down to RT.

FTIR, NMR, GPC and rheology were carried out to characterize the molecular structure of POSS-PMMA with different arm lengths. The signals at 1731 cm−1 and 1130 cm−1 of PMMA and POSS are belonged to the stretching vibration of –CO and -Si-O-Si- groups [36]. The characteristic C–Cl group at 700 cm−1 disappears after the reaction as shown in Fig. 2 a, demonstrating the expected polymerization of POSS and PMMA. The 1H NMR spectra of POSS-PMMA are also employed to evaluate the polymerization in Fig. 2b. The signals of POSS-PMMA located at around 3.6 ppm are attributed to the methyl on carbonyl (COOCH3), and the proton of CH2Cl disappears at 3.5 ppm, indicating the MMA have been grafted on the POSS core successfully [37,38]. The GPC curves of POSS-PMMA with different arm lengths are shown in Fig. 2c, and the homologous molecular characterization results of the grafted polymers are shown in Table 1 . The polymer dispersion index (PDI) is less than 2, inferring that the structure and molecular weight of POSS-PMMA are well controlled. The DSC curves in Fig. 2d show the changes of glass transition temperatures (T g) in POSS-PMMA with different arm lengths. It can be found that T g of POSS-PMMA decreases and then increases with the arm length, reaching a minimum at 200 arm length. The slightly higher T g value of POSS-PMMA with shorter arm length could be attributed to the relatively higher content of POSS, which restricts the organic chain motions [39]. With the increase of arm length, this restriction is weakened and thus leads to a lower T g. However, as the arm length increases further, the chain entanglement restricts the chain motions, which as a dominated factor results in a higher T g [40]. The DSC curves of POSS-PMMA based GPEs in Fig. S2 also shows a similar trend. Fig. 2e is the rheology master curves of POSS-PMMA with different arm lengths at a reference temperature of 150 °C. With the increase of arm length, the frequency range of the rubber plateau area gradually becomes broader. The number of entanglements per chain Z (
M w b
/M
e, where M
e is the entanglement molecular weight, and the M e of PMMA is 10013 g/mol) of samples with arm lengths of 120, 200, and 550 are 2, 4, and 9, respectively, indicating the synthesized POSS-PMMA are entangled [41]. The schematic illustration of the crosslinked POSS-PMMA is revealed in Fig. 2e. Although entanglement greatly improves the mechanical properties and processability of POSS-PMMA, the electrochemical properties is reduced due to the lower lithium ion transfer caused by segment activity restrictions [32]. The key to overcome the difficulty lying in finding a delicate balance between electrochemical and mechanical properties is to adjust the arm length of the POSS-PMMA.

High ionic conductivity, wide electrochemical window and excellent lithium ion migration number are the key parameter for evaluating GPEs. Fig. 3 a displays the corresponding ionic conductivity σ of POSS-PMMA based GPEs with different arm lengths. The ionic conductivity of POSS-PMMA based GPEs increases and then decreases with the increase of arm length, achieving a maximum value of 3.5 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 200 arm length. The dependence of σ on the arm length of POSS-PMMA is consistent with that of T g. This means the segmental motion of polymer chains as a dominant factor affect the ion conductivity. Specifically, the faster segment motion or larger free volume leads to accelerated transfer of Li ions at the temperature above T g [17]. As demonstrated in Fig. 2d, POSS-PMMA-200 has a lowest T g, which implies that the coupling effect of reduced restriction of POSS and slight entanglement for POSS-PMMA-200 could lead to a much better mobility of PMMA segments and result in faster transmission of lithium ions, thereby rendering higher ionic conductivity. The value of apparent activation energy (Ea) for 200 arm length is minimum in Fig. S3, manifesting a lowest energy barrier of Li+ transfer. The SEM image and corresponding EDS mappings of silicon and fluorine in Fig. S4 shows the good compatibility of the matrix, ionic liquid and lithium salt of POSS-PMMA based GPE with 200 arm length. Therefore, POSS-PMMA-200 is selected for other performance tests of POSS-PMMA based GPE, with PMMA based GPE with a similar molecular weight of 120000 g/mol.

The activation energy of POSS-PMMA based gel electrolyte is much lower than that of PMMA as depicted in Fig. 3b, indicating the introduction of POSS resulting a lower energy barrier [42]. The electrochemical window is measured by linear sweep voltammetry in Fig. 3c. The oxidative decomposition occurs at about 4.9 V, which is higher than the commercial standard of 4.2 V and meet most cathode materials such as LFP and NCM811 [43]. The reason for the broad electrochemically stable window of POSS-PMMA based GPE is that POSS with inorganic core can suppress electrode/electrolyte interactions and increase the oxidative decomposition voltage of electrolyte [44]. The tLi+ is also a key factor affecting ionic conductivity. The tLi+ of POSS-PMMA-200 based GPE is measured and calculated in Fig. 3d, which can reach to an ideal level of 0.35. The increase in Li+ migration can be attributed to the channels for the migration of lithium of POSS [30]. The fast transmission of lithium ions is illustrated by Fig. 3g. The dispersion of polymer chains becomes complete and effective due to the crosslinked structure, which enhances the effective contact of the carbonyl groups with liquid electrolyte. Furthermore, POSS provides channels for the migration of lithium ions due to the three-dimensional nano-structure. Consequently, the fast transmission of lithium ions can be achieved.

Despite the addition of a small amount of PMMA in electrolyte is conducive to the formation of a uniform lithium deposit on the electrode surface, high content of PMMA adversely contributes to the composition of SEI due to its insulation, resulting in uneven lithium deposition on the electrode surface [46]. Therefore, PPCE is prepared as a surface coating constituted of SN, LiTFSI, fluoroethylene carbonate and PEO to build a stable interface between lithium metal and the GPE [47,48]. As a common plasticizing polymer, SN displays an ionic conductivity about 1 mS cm−1 mixed with a lithium salt with a SN to Li+ molar ratio of 20:1, and inhibits the crystallization of PEO, which provides mechanical strength and processability. From the XRD patterns in Fig. 4 a, the crystallization peak of LiTFSI disappears and only one wide peak of PEO is expressed, indicating that SN has a good solubility for LiTFSI and PEO. The Nyquist plots of Li symmetric cells with PPCE modification layer (Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||Li) and without PPCE modification layer (Li||POSS-PMMA||Li) are significantly different in Fig. 4b. The interfacial impedance of the Li||POSS-PMMA||Li cell is extremely large at 62440 Ω, which stands in sharp contrast to the interfacial impedance of the Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||Li cell at 1138 Ω dropped by about 55 times.

The Li/GPE interfacial stability of electrolyte during the Li stripping/plating was investigated by Li symmetric batteries at RT as shown in Fig. 4c. The Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||Li cell exhibits a long stable cycle for 1000 h at the current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 and a significantly lower overpotential during Li stripping/plating, which is sufficient to prove the excellent interface compatibility between POSS-PMMA-PPCE and Li electrodes. It is worth noting that the overpotential of Li||PMMA||Li and Li||POSS-PMMA||Li rise sharply at the beginning of the cycle, indicating that they have caused serious interface deterioration. As depicted in Fig. 4d, the POSS-PMMA-PPCE cell can still be cycled for more than 50 h at the current density of 0.2 mA cm−2. After 50 h of cycling, the surface morphology of lithium metal of Li||PMMA||Li cell and Li||POSS-PMMA||Li cell show an obvious porous and loose morphology with crack caused by the uneven lithium depositon in Fig. 4e [12]. In contrast, the flat surface of the lithium sheet in the Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||Li cell has the original metallic luster of lithium. The result shows that PPCE coating on POSS-PMMA can induce uniform lithium deposition and reduce the formation of lithium dendrites.

XPS was performed to analyze the microstructure and the composition of SEI on the surface of lithium metal electrodes in different Li symmetric batteries after 50 h of cycling. The characteristic peaks of CO is derived from the carbonyl group of PMMA and FEC in the C 1s spectra in Fig. 5 a. The F 1s spectra of the GPEs show that the substances containing F element in SEI come from LiTFSI and [EMIM][TFSI] in Fig. 5b. As shown in Fig. 5c, the content of Li3N in the SEI layer of POSS-PMMA-PPCE is higher than that of PMMA and POSS-PMMA. As an inorganic component in the SEI of lithium metal battery systems, Li3N is a Li+ super-conductor which can promote interfacial ion transport and stabilize the SEI [49,50]. It can be explained that the N atom in the locally negatively charged N of –C N in SN and the locally positively charged C atom of -O-C in PMMA can generate a dipole-dipole interaction, resulting in the reduction of the C–N in the SEI layer to Li3N [51,52]. The Si–O signal from the Si 2p spectra in Fig. 5d of POSS-PMMA-PPCE can be clearly detected, and the Si–O in SEI can provide strong support role [53], thus effectively inhibiting the growth of lithium dendrites towards the electrolyte side. The role of PPCE coating and POSS for Li/GPE interface is illustrated in Fig. 5e. On one hand, PPCE has a strong interfacial contact with Li electrode, so that the voids between GPE and lithium metal are filled, facilitating the soft contact between Li and GPE. On the other hand, the lithium ion migration channels provided by POSS and Li3N reduced from SN promotes the fast transmission of lithium ions. Consequently,a rigid ionic conductive interface layer at the Li/GPE interface is formed, which can effectively prevent the problem of Li+ nucleation at the bulge and enable uniform Li deposition.

The Li||POSS-PMMA||LFP and Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||LFP full cells were assembled to evaluate the rate performance of POSS-PMMA-PPCE at RT in Fig. 6 a. The initial capacity of Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||LFP battery is 114.9 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C, decreases to 33.1 mAh g−1 at 1 C, and then increases back to 102.1 mAh g−1, indicating a stable electrode/electrolyte interface with strong reversibility [54]. In sharp contrast, the Li||POSS-PMMA||LFP battery shows an extremely low discharge capacity (6.4 mAh g−1) at 0.1 C due to the low stability of the ester functional group of PMMA with Li metal [55], highlighting the role of POSS-PMMA-PPCE in reducing side reactions and lithium dendrites. The charging-discharging curves show a long charge-recharge platform of Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||LFP battery in Fig. 6b, demonstrating that POSS-PMMA-PPCE has a good interfacial stability with a low overpotential (≈190 mV).

To explore the long-term charge and discharge performance of the batteries, the cycling tests at 0.2 C and RT were performed in Fig. 6c. The Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||LFP battery can obtain an initial capacity of 114.9 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C and a Coulombic efficiency of 81.5 %, attributed to SEI which consumes the limited lithium ions in the electrolyte and cathode material [56]. The Li||PMMA||LFP battery and Li||POSS-PMMA||LFP battery can't performs properly due to the insulation and poor interface of high PMMA content, which is consistent with Fig. 5a–d and Fig. 6a. The Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||LFP battery maintains a discharge capacity of 114.3 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles with a capacity retention rate of 99.5 %, demonstrating a long-term stability significantly improved compared with GPEs without PPCE coating. The increase of discharge capacity was observed in the early cycle, attributed to the gradual infiltration of FEC into the voids between the electrolyte and the electrode and the electrolyte activation during cycling. The Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||LFP battery exhibits a stable long-term cycling and low polarization, which means that POSS-PMMA-PPCE has unimpeded transmission of lithium ions at the interface.

As shown in Fig. 3c, the synthesized POSS-PMMA has a wide electrochemical window of up to 4.9 V, so high voltage batteries with NCM811 were assembled for the rate and cycle performance tests. The rate performance of POSS-PMMA-PPCE was measured at the operating potential 3.0–4.3 V different from 2.5 to 4.0 V of LFP cells at RT in Fig. 6d and e. The initial discharge capacity of Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||NCM811 battery is 95.4 mAh g−1, as the rate returns back to 0.1C, reversible discharge capacity of about 102.3 mAh g−1 is delivered. In contrast, the Li||POSS-PMMA||NCM811 battery fails to work well. Cycling tests of high voltage batteries are performed to examine their long-term stability in Fig. 6f. The Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||NCM811 battery can still maintain a discharge capacity of 93.6 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles, and the capacity retention rate is 88.3 %, which is significantly higher than the discharge capacity of 29.2 mAh g−1 of Li||POSS-PMMA||NCM811 battery after 50 cycles. It is proved that POSS-PMMA-PPCE also has far better electrochemical performance than POSS-PMMA in high-voltage batteries.

In this work, an eight-arm star polymer matrix grafted PMMA on POSS was successfully synthesized by ATRP method, and it was mixed with [EMIM][TFSI] and LiTFSI to prepare gel electrolyte by co-solvent volatilization. POSS can not only significantly improve the mechanical strength of the matrix as a crosslinking point, but also serve as a lithium ion migration channel to achieve rapid transfer of lithium ions. Therefore, the prepared GPE combines excellent electrochemical properties, mechanical strength and thermal stability. The best-performing POSS-PMMA based GPE exhibits an ionic conductivity of 3.5 × 10−4 S cm−1, an electrochemical window of 4.9 V, and a Li-ion migration number of 0.35. Moreover, by coating PPCE on the surface, the layered GPE was prepared to improve its interface performance. PMMA could induce the SN in the coating to form Li3N, speeding up the transfer of lithium ions and achieving the uniform deposition of lithium at the interface. The Li symmetric battery assembled with synthesized POSS-PMMA-PPCE can achieve an ultra-long and stable Li stripping/plating cycle up to 1000 h with a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2. Besides, the assembled Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||LFP cell has a capacity retention rate of 99.5 % after 100 cycles at 0.2 C and RT. The high voltage battery Li||POSS-PMMA-PPCE||NCM811 cell is improved in terms of cycle performance. This work provides a reference for improving the electrochemical properties of polymer based gel electrolytes by introducing star structure and interfacial coating.

Jinqi Chen: Writing – original draft, Formal analysis, Conceptualization. Cong Luo: Investigation, Formal analysis, Conceptualization. Yanhua Niu: Writing – review & editing. Guangxian Li: Writing – review & editing.
